title: Conservation of energy - spring and projectile

content.question: A ball of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is loaded into a launcher with a spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>. The ball is pushed down until it is at a vertical position <math alttext="y equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, and the spring is compressed a distance <math alttext="delta L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>L</mi></math>, as shown. The ball is then released from rest. Immediately after leaving the launcher, the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>- and <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-components of the ball’s velocity are <math alttext="v sub x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="v sub y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></math>, respectively. The ball reaches a maximum height of <math alttext="y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math> and lands a horizontal distance <math alttext="delta x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>x</mi></math> away from its initial position. Energy losses due to friction are negligible. Which of the following is a correct conservation of energy equation that compares the total mechanical energy of the ball-spring-Earth system immediately before the ball is launched to the total mechanical energy of the ball-spring-Earth system the moment the ball reaches its maximum height?

choices.label: <math alttext="one half k delta L squared, plus one half m times, open parenthesis, v sub x, end sub, squared, plus v sub y, end sub, squared, close parenthesis, equals m g y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>k</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>

<math alttext="one half k delta L squared, plus m g delta x, equals one half m times v sub x, end sub, squared, plus m g y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>k</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>

<math alttext="one half k delta L squared, equals one half m times v sub x, end sub, squared, plus m g y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>k</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>

<math alttext="one half k delta L squared, equals m g y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>k</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="one half k delta L squared, equals one half m times v sub x, end sub, squared, plus m g y sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>k</mi><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
